comments.commentBody:
“The people who have been sent to Washington most recently are bringing a strong message from the Republicans more to the right that really want something done about government spending,” said Joseph E. Kasputys...

A somewhat innocuous statement with a deceptively incorrect conclusion. In fact, those House Republicans were elected by a majority of voters in their districts - not "Republicans more to the right." The message is much more broadly felt and sent than implied by this poorly reasoned, simplistic comment.

In fact, the American people clearly understand that increasing the debt without changing the ways of government is folly. Those who believe that not raising the debt is folly are correct to a point. That point is a legally binding commitment to reduce spending. If we must raise taxes (and I personally believe we should), any tax increase should touch 80-90% of households - even in a modest way for those of modest means.

The binding force of our republic is our common destiny but that force and that destiny require a common sacrifice. Without that shared commitment, the destiny of our nation is fated to be that of parochial and ineffective bickering (if we're not there already).

"Isn’t there another company out there with some new ideas to offer?" Well there are, they just are smaller lines, with GREAT ideas! As a denim designer and owner of my own small denim line it is sad that large retailers do not ever pick up small lines that do amazing things. As an independent designer without the ability to have a sales rep chum up the Bloomingdales buyer it is basically impossible to get buyers to even consider us. So why not get a to rep the line? There are a lot of bad sales reps that really will not do anything except collect rent fee, it has happened so back to the indie direction. The point is smaller lines offer great incentives usually produced domestically, higher quality, and care in the design and innovation, that is what's so special about independent designers, we care so much and you can tell in the details. Long story short, look for what's new, and give some support young new designers. Try it you'll like it!

www.kentdenim.com

Colored jeans are so amazing. I love the fact that they are a easy way to spice up a white tee or a simple button down. Great trend.

www.greeneggsandglam.blogspot.com

I love to see bright colors for spring and for summer! Gets us out of the drab of the fall and winter. Nothing like alot of color to look and feel great.
http://www.justinbootsforwomen.org

I love color, and it's sometimes hard to find in men's clothing. But yesterday I picked up some new Billy Reid and the color is great. And my Etro green cords have been a perfect transitional pair from winter through a chilly spring.

http://www.josephthebutler.blogspot.com

I totally agree, this spring/summer is all about vibrant colours. Now everyone is embrace bold colours, including boys.
Colourfull pants (jeans) is one way for summer. But for those who still shy of wearing yellow pants for example, should try short pants first.

http://titoley.wordpress.com/2011/04/28/men%e2%80%99s-springsummer-style...

I love living in Snoburbia where we are all underwater on our mortgages (some of by close to $200,000!) but nobody ever questions why we spend money on expensive landscaping, ATVs, passes at the ski restort, and alfresco dining on the town square. Hey, most of us are just trying to forget we could get pink slipped at any time, have to give the house back to the bank and live in our oversized cars! Not me of course since my parents and in-laws have plenty of room for us and the dogs.

Where is all this judgment coming from of this young woman who clearly hasn't had many of the educational and financial advantages that most NYTimes readers have enjoyed?? Hey, I'm paying the on-line subscription but, again, nobody questions my choices! How many of the critics questioning this program can honestly say "I did it all myself"? As I recall, Daddy paid for all my years of higher education, helped me get not one but two internships, gave me a succession of cars AND helped with the down payments for my first two houses. The in-laws paid for the wedding.

It's easy to sit in judgment of a poor, single mom (who smokes!) when you had goals made easily attainable by involved parents, a stable upbringing and enough money to never worry about whether you'll have dinner or hot water. The assumption, made atop ivory towers, is just that she's gaming the system, not trying hard enough, and too irresponsible to use birth control. Any of you critics ever not report just a little bit of income? How about use your home equity as an ATM? Any of you ladies ever forget to take your pill? And, don't get me started on your BMI! Jeez, talk about casting the first stone.

I see a young woman taking responsibility for her life and her decisions, working to provide her daughter with a stable home life. I see a strong mother doing her best in difficult circumstances. I see a human example of underemployment, and an assistance program providing a net and an encouragement for a better future.

I see a child who is currently living in an apartment with her employed mother. I see a woman trying to maintain that stability for her child. Look at the future. She is hobbling along in a little pink outfit. And her present circumstances affect the future for us all.

Politicians and the upper echelon financial folks may be able to live in the short term, but the rest of us really need to have a bit more pragmatic long term perspective.

For crying out loud.

So let me get this straight:
When adults smoke dried plants and molasses- that's a no-no.

When adults gut the constitution, lie us into perpetual war, and scam the financial and housing markets to the tune of economic collapse- that's a yes-yes (win/win).

Please find something important to write about.

But Mr. Tourre must have acted alone.  If not, then many more at Goldman would have been complicit, and prosecuting them might undermine the entire company.  That can't be allowed to happen, because if Goldman collapses, then were are the investigators going to get jobs once their stint at the SEC has ended?  So you see, Goldman can't have known about the actions of this one fall guy.

Earth to the New York Times: There haven't been any criminal prosecutions of the big names on Wall Street because those big names run this country.

So instead of having people pay for their bad bets like a degenerate gambler loading up on the hard eight at the craps table, they get bailed out like a rich kid who gets a new BMW after crashing his old one. Meanwhile the peasants are fed a steady diet of lackluster insider trading cases (like insider trading hasn't happened since the dawn of the markets) to quench their thirst for justice.

Unfortunately, justice hasn't been done as our country still has millions unemployed while Wall Street continues to go unregulated with their heads in the taxpayer trough so that they can enjoy their unjustified salaries.

Maybe our leaders in D.C. will realize the err of their ways when another financial crisis happens and the peasantry finally says enough.

It's not exactly the burning bush when one pervasive element from the Spring collections trickles into mainstream fashion unless the Moses you're referencing is named Rebecca. It's an easy out when those unable to purchase a $3000. skirt from JilSander can purchase a $200. pair of jeans from JBrand; salon meets the street through a side entrance. Regardless, only mid-to-dark skins favour the jarringly jeweled tones to full effect; anyone else resembles an LED on LSD. There's nothing wrong feeling proud of your newly installed halogen headlamps, capable of illuminating houses three blocks downwind that drive oncoming drivers to distraction, it's the disappointment you'll feel next month when your purchase's outdated & even eBay buyers pop your thin-skinned balloon. I feel for those who buy into trends; reminds me of the traveling salesmen who peddle cure-all tonics when essentially, it's just coloured water.

If one big state, like California or New York, put a stake in the ground and said that it would hold its primary first, no matter what (the same threat that Iowa and NH make), they would a) break the system and b) force change. Several small or mid-sized states doing the same thing would work, too.

The crazy thing is that this doesn't require change at the federal level -- any individual state can solve this problem. They just need somebody with some political chutzpah to start the ball rolling.

Another instance of high-end letting someone else make money off their idea? The purpose? Geez Louise. Good for J-Brand for picking up on what a lot of people, including on this blog, sensed after seeing Jil Sander's colors, it or that as being a good idea. This ain't exactly rocket science, is it?

Living in New Hampshire the past four years, I have seen firsthand the positive impact of the first primary in creating a lively retail political culture in the state. I like the idea of a rotating system, but it would be a shame if the extraordinary energy of ordinary citizens involved politics in these early primary/caucus were to be lost. Is there a way to make the nominating process fairer and still build up a thriving public political culture?

Secondly, I see that Iowa gets rewarded with ethanol subsidies, but what does New Hampshire get out of this deal?
You can also get jeans in bright hues for a while now, for $40.
I forgot to mention you can get those bright colored jeans for $40 at Zara.
Whenever a man casts a longing eye on offices, a rottenness begins in his conduct. Thomas Jefferson

Another angle to the default situation is that it can be very profitable. If you and your fellow congressmen know you're going to default, then how many will'short' the market, and make a killing? We'd probably never know, but very rarely does congress have the power to cause an immediate recesssion, and seem so likely to do it. Think about that, as your portfolio sinks rapidly into the sunset.
Wall Street is in on the joke.  Again.

1. Michelle Obama looked comfortable in her own skin, polished and with rich, spring colors that complemented her dark skin.
2. If you equate thinness with looking good, then yes, Duchess Cambridge looked good. With her olive skin, the Duchess would have looked better in the same sorts of tones that Mrs. Obama wore.
3. Lastly, people, unless you have had an audience with the Queen, stop saying that what Mrs. Obama wore was "inappropiate". Quick recap: she's a Ivy League educated lawyer who also happens to have stylists and etiquette managers on hand. You, the commenters, do not. Not only was Mrs. Obama's outfits appropriate for each and every occasion, but very similar to how other royalty are dressed when meeting the Queen.

PS: You were a hat or a head covering to meet the Pope, not the Queen.

When we return to a world without cell phones, cable, flat-screen TV, computers, ipods, VCR's, DVD's, webcams, digital cameras, etc. then we will return to hospitals without MRI's, CAT SCANs, digital thermometers, nuclear tests, PET Scans, heart monitors, sonograms, mammograms, etc. etc. and the healthcare system will be far less expensive.

#16-"so your view is that the opposition tortured this boy "

Most boys have much critical information worth torturing them for, certainly not anything that you can't get out of them with $50 and a couple of candy bars.

And the question remains, why would they return the body to the parents?

Creative urgency is a really interesting point. Unfortunately I don't think it is that simple.

As someone in my late 20's working for a luxury house in Paris, I often experience bouts of creative urgency which are then dampened by the harsh realities of how hard and how impossible it is to have a viable creative business these days. For me, I thought that working for a luxury house was the only viable avenue to (eventually) having a creative vision that was grounded is some kind of commercial reality. Now I'm not so sure - that idea stands to be tested.

I watch so many 'young designers' get creatively worn down by the commercial realities and the industry's hunger for a knock out collection every six months. So many of my friends in the industry, still in their twenties are already burnt out. Surely the pace of the industry has something to answer for? It feels like the spirit of fashion, that love, the whim and fantasy is dying. It feels like it is just turning into a big commercial grind, and I fear that if I ever take a chance to put myself out there, I will just get chewed up and spat out like the rest of them. All I see in front of me is a harsh battlefield.

I don't think you can blame a lack of creative urgency. Of course, you have to have that element there. You also have to remember that designers, by nature, are sensitive people, very few are born with a brash determination. I think you have to consider that, unfortunately, we are dealing with a very different world today than we ever have before.

The primary reason I no longer stand for the National Anthem.
Carl, Portland
